projects.name: Morning Glories

steps.instruction: Cut five petal segments using template MG from outstretched blue crepe paper in your desired hue. Attach two segments together face-to-face with a line of tacky glue along one edge, starting a hair wider than 1⁄16” at the base and tapering to a very thin line at the top. Press together to set, then gently open the petals, turn them over and glue the back flap down from the bend in the petal to the base. Repeat with the remaining petal segments, gluing the flaps down in the same direction each time.

Crease the centerline of each petal segment inward, then repeat step 1 with the two unattached ends to close the flower and glue the back flap down. Insert a round-ended paintbrush and twist the bottom tip closed below the end. Groom the top open by bending the petals back at each seam gently.

Trim the seam corners to round the top of the flower. Cut tiny Vs with rounded edges where the petal segments meet and at their centers. If bleaching, dip a round, pointed paintbrush in a small glass bowl of bleach, wipe off the excess, and insert into the flower's base, bleaching the bottom. Carefully extract the brush, then run the tip up the center of the back of each petal segment to ¾” below the top edge. Allow to dry. Be sure to work in a well-ventilated area. For a tricolored flower, glue small segments of finely fringed outstretched white crepe paper to the inner petal surfaces before closing.

Wrap the top 1½” of two 2”-and one 8”-long pieces of stem wire with outstretched white crepe. Wrap the wires together with floral tape, the 2” pieces set ¾” below the 8” piece, leaving most of the white exposed. Snip the twisted bottom end from the flower and thread the wrapped wire through, aligning the tip of the wires with the bend in the petals. Secure in place with hot glue. Cut five continuous sepal points from a 5/8”-long bit of floral tape and attach at the base of the flower with tacky glue, holding in place until set. Wrap leaf and flower wires around a ¼” paintbrush handle 3 or 4 times in a few different spots to mimic the morning glory’s spiraling vines.
steps.technique: wrapping, snipping, threading, gluing, cutting, attaching

tips: This is not the most precise or accurate flower in my arsenal, by any stretch, but it is quick and fun. Try it in shades of red, pink, purple, and white.

projects.name: DIY Paper garland swag for send-off car

steps.instruction: We opted for two types of leaves for our garland. For both, use the templates provided.

Cut out the leaves, with the template lying parallel to the grain of the crepe paper. You’ll need 10-15 leaves for each bough. The number of boughs will depend upon the size of the car and the desired fullness of the garland.
For the pointier leaves, glue a large leaf at the end of the wire, about 1 inch up the leaf.
Continue gluing on leaves, decreasing in size as you go up, along the floral wire. Overlap the leaves a little and just glue on the base of the leaf.
For the rounder leaves, Cut small lengths of wire, about 3 inches long.
Glue the wire pieces to the back and base of the leaves, extending ½ inch up.
Begin attaching the wired leaves to a piece of floral wire, starting with a big leaf at one end and decreasing in size as you go up.
The wire allows the leaves more movement and flow, to appear like Eucalyptus leaves.

tips: Crepe paper is dyed and when it gets wet it will dye your car. So, it must only be used in dry weather.

projects.name: Paper Ranunculus Flowers

materials.color: various (for watercolor wash, light green for centers, green or variation for leaves)

tools.name: cutting machine
tools.purpose: cutting flower petals from SVG file

tools.name: scissors
tools.purpose: cutting flower petals from PDF file

steps.instruction: Apply a watercolor wash over the paper to create texture (optional, or download textured paper).
Choose a light green paper for the flower centers and green or a slight variation for the leaves.
Download the template for the flowers (PDF for hand cutting or SVG for cutting machine).
Cut out all petals and pieces using the chosen method.
Begin forming the flower center by using a foam ball or creating a small paper ball. Keep this ball in the center until the very end of assembly.
As you add each layer of paper petals, twist them together to create a dense, tightly arranged bloom.
Ensure individual petals in each cut-out are stacked on top of each other. Place each petal on top of the petal to its right (or left) consistently in a circle around the bloom.
After adding each layer of petals, gently smash the petals a bit.
Once all petals are glued, gently open the center of the flower and remove the foam or paper ball.

tips: Twist petals together as you add each layer to make the bloom appear more tightly arranged.
Stack individual petals on top of each other.
Place every petal on top of the petal to its right (or left) consistently in a circle.
Gently smash petals after adding each layer.

projects.name: Metallic Paper Ranunculus Flower

materials.item: small foam ball or rolled paper ball

tools.name: scissors
tools.purpose: trimming petals and leaves, curling petals

tools.name: hot glue gun
tools.purpose: gluing layers of petals and leaves

steps.instruction: Gather your materials. Print watercolor image onto white pearl paper.
steps.visual_description: A flat lay of craft materials including white pearl paper, green paper, scissors, and a hot glue gun.

steps.instruction: Trim all petals and leaves as noted on pattern.
steps.visual_description: Various sizes of cut-out white flower petals and green leaves arranged on a dark surface.

steps.instruction: Curl all petals with edge of scissors.
steps.visual_description: A hand holding a white petal, using scissors to curl its edge. Several other curled petals are visible.

steps.instruction: Starting with smallest green petal, place small foam ball or rolled paper ball in center. Fold petals around ball in a spiral.
steps.visual_description: A small green petal with a white foam ball placed in its center, with the petal edges starting to be folded around the ball.

steps.instruction: Press tightly running fingers around petals to form.
steps.visual_description: A hand holding a tightly rolled green paper piece, pressing it to form.

steps.instruction: With fingernails, crush edges of petals to create texture.
steps.visual_description: A hand using fingernails to crush the edges of the green paper piece, creating texture.

steps.instruction: Glue second layer onto back of center and repeat the spiral. Repeat steps 5 & 6 with every layer.
steps.visual_description: A green paper flower base with a glue gun applying glue to its center, next to another green petal piece.

steps.instruction: Continue with pink petals, rotating each layer of petals and crushing bottom corners to secure with each layer.
steps.visual_description: A hand holding a pink petal layer, applying glue with a glue gun, with a partially assembled flower visible.

steps.instruction: Finish with 8th layer of petals.
steps.visual_description: A top-down view of a partially assembled ranunculus flower, showing multiple layers of pink petals and a green center.

steps.instruction: Remove foam ball from center green.
steps.visual_description: A top-down view of the assembled ranunculus flower, with the green center visible and a small white foam ball next to it, indicating its removal.

steps.instruction: Gently crush bloom with palm of hand.
steps.visual_description: A hand gently crushing the assembled ranunculus flower with the palm.

steps.instruction: Fold leaves down each center.
steps.visual_description: Several green and white leaf cutouts, some folded along their center veins.

steps.instruction: Glue leaf onto back of each bloom.
steps.visual_description: A hand applying glue with a glue gun to the back of a green leaf, which is being attached to the back of a ranunculus flower.

steps.instruction: No explicit instruction, but shows the final assembly.
steps.visual_description: A close-up of two finished metallic paper ranunculus flowers with green leaves attached, arranged on a dark surface.

blueprint_data.assembly_notes: Layer petals in a spiral, starting with the smallest green petal around a foam ball. Crush petal edges for texture. Attach folded leaves to the back of the finished bloom.

projects.name: Heart Shaped Topiary

materials.item: Crepe Paper [Double Sided: Green Tea & Cypress + Ferns & Moss]

steps.instruction: Gather the tools and materials listed above.
Print the PDF template below and cut your crepe leaves according to the pattern.
Bend the copper wire into a heart shape.
steps.visual_description: A heart shape made of copper wire.

steps.instruction: Slightly stretch the leaves to make them more cup-like, then use hot glue to attach the leaves directly to the wire.
steps.visual_description: Crepe paper leaves being attached to the wire heart.

steps.instruction: Place a piece of foam into your pot, cover it with dried moss, then secure the wire heart into the foam.
steps.visual_description: A terra cotta pot filled with moss, with the wire heart topiary secured in place.

tips: You can use various materials for the heart-shaped base, such as flat copper wire, paper-covered floral wire, or other metallic wires.
Don't worry about bending the wire perfectly, as imperfections can be covered with crepe paper.
The size of the heart and pot can be adjusted as desired, but ensure they look balanced.
Hold the wire against a flat surface while bending to ensure an even shape.
The technique is similar to the 'Potted Plant Series'.
Tie a ribbon around the pot for extra color.
The finished topiary can be displayed as a centerpiece or as part of a DIY wedding decoration set.

The flower has multiple layers of petals, with the center showing a tighter bud-like structure in shades of deep pink and green, transitioning to lighter peach and pink tones on the outer petals. The edges of the petals appear slightly ruffled and textured. The flower is resting on a decorative, ornate white surface that resembles carved plaster or stone, with a slightly distressed appearance. In the background, other similar flowers in soft pink and green hues are visible, also out of focus. A subtle watermark or graphic overlay reads 'Crafted by Chelsea Le' and 'craftinglifespieces.blogspot.com'.

A collection of craft supplies including a pink heat gun, a blue hot glue gun, a Winsor & Newton Cotman watercolor palette, a Shapez Creatopia flower die cut, and a Spellbinders Nestabilities flower die cut. There are also some delicate paper flowers in the foreground.

projects.name: Paper Cherry Blossoms

steps.instruction: Cut out 5 petal shapes from the light pink crepe paper. Each petal should be about 1.5 inches long and 0.75 inches wide. Cut out 2 leaf shapes from the green crepe paper, each about 1 inch long and 0.5 inches wide.
steps.visual_description: Five petal shapes and two leaf shapes cut from crepe paper.

steps.instruction: Gently stretch the center of each petal and leaf to give them a curved, natural look.
steps.visual_description: Crepe paper petals and leaves being gently stretched.

steps.instruction: For each flower, take one piece of brown floral wire and wrap the end with a small amount of brown floral tape. Add a dab of hot glue to the taped end and attach 5 petals around it, forming a flower shape. Add a dab of hot glue to the center of the flower and attach a small piece of yellow paper or a bead for the stamen.
steps.visual_description: Assembling paper flowers by attaching petals to floral wire and adding a stamen.

steps.instruction: Attach the green leaves to the floral wire stems, near the flowers, using brown floral tape.
steps.visual_description: Attaching paper leaves to the floral wire stems.

steps.instruction: Create several branches by twisting together 2-3 pieces of floral wire. Wrap the twisted wires with brown floral tape to create a branch-like texture.
steps.visual_description: Creating branches by twisting and taping floral wires.

steps.instruction: Attach the paper flowers and leaves to the branches, securing them with brown floral tape. Vary the placement and angles of the flowers and leaves to create a natural look.
steps.visual_description: Attaching paper flowers and leaves to the branches.

steps.instruction: Cut a piece of floral foam to fit snugly inside the white pot. Insert the main branches into the floral foam, arranging them to create a tree shape.
steps.visual_description: Inserting branches into floral foam inside a pot.

steps.instruction: Cover the floral foam with moss, tucking it around the base of the branches to create a natural ground cover.
steps.visual_description: Covering floral foam with moss.

tips: For a more realistic look, use a paintbrush to apply a light wash of pink watercolor to the edges of the petals.
You can adjust the size of the petals and leaves to create different sizes of flowers.

projects.name: Crepe Paper Magnolia Flowers

steps.instruction: Gather your materials.
steps.visual_description: Rolls of green, white/cream, and yellow crepe paper, floral wires, white foam balls, scissors, a glue gun, and a pattern sheet laid out on a surface.

steps.instruction: Trim all of the pieces as marked on the pattern.
steps.visual_description: Cut pieces of crepe paper including several white/cream petals of varying sizes, green leaves, and two rectangular strips (one yellow, one white/cream), next to a pair of scissors.

steps.instruction: Fringe the two center strips.

steps.instruction: Fold top edge of the yellow strip. Glue a 1 inch foam ball onto a floral wire.
steps.visual_description: A yellow fringed strip with its top edge folded over. Separately, a 1-inch white foam ball is shown glued onto the end of a green floral wire, with a glue gun nearby.

steps.instruction: Starting at the top of the ball, glue fringe onto foam.

steps.instruction: Spiral fringe around ball leaving a bit of the ball showing.

steps.instruction: Finish covering ball with white fringe.
steps.visual_description: The foam ball is now fully covered with both yellow and white fringe, creating a textured flower center. A glue gun is shown next to it.

steps.instruction: Stretch the centers of each of the petals to form cups.
steps.visual_description: Several white/cream crepe paper petals are shown; some are flat, while others have been stretched in their centers to form a cup-like shape.

steps.instruction: Arrange first three petals around wire and under ball and wrap with floral tape.
steps.visual_description: Three stretched white/cream petals are arranged around the base of the fringed ball and wire, secured with green floral tape wrapped around the stem.

steps.instruction: Arrange second set of three petals and wrap with floral tape.
steps.visual_description: Another three stretched white/cream petals are arranged around the first set, further building the flower, and secured with green floral tape.

steps.instruction: Add final petals (optional).
steps.visual_description: A hand is holding a nearly complete magnolia flower, adding more white/cream petals to create a fuller bloom. Green floral tape is visible on the stem.

steps.instruction: Stretch centers of leaves.
steps.visual_description: Several green crepe paper leaves are shown; some are flat, while others have been stretched in their centers to give them a natural curve.

steps.instruction: Tape two leaves under bloom and the third a few inches down the stem.
steps.visual_description: Two stretched green leaves are taped directly beneath the flower bloom, and a third stretched green leaf is taped further down the stem, a few inches below the first two. Green floral tape is visible.

steps.instruction: Cover stem with floral tape.
steps.visual_description: The entire floral wire stem is wrapped smoothly with green floral tape. A pair of scissors and a roll of floral tape are next to the finished stem.

blueprint_data.assembly_notes: The flower center is made by gluing fringed strips around a foam ball on a wire. Petals are stretched and then taped in layers around the center. Leaves are stretched and taped to the stem.

steps.visual_description: White paper petals arranged on a brown surface, with a palette of green and blue paint and a brush.

steps.instruction: Gather 30 wires at 12 inches long, starting 2-3 inches below tip, wrap stem with floral tape.
steps.visual_description: A bundle of 30 wires, 12 inches long, being wrapped with green floral tape starting 2-3 inches from the tip.

steps.instruction: Bend top of stem to create a half circle spray.
steps.visual_description: The top of the wire bundle is bent into a half-circle shape, resembling a spray of spokes.

steps.instruction: Curl lighter paper with edge of scissors.
steps.visual_description: A paper petal is being curled using the edge of a pair of scissors.

steps.instruction: Or curl cardstock petals around pencil.
steps.visual_description: A paper petal is being curled around a green pencil.

steps.instruction: Glue first 30 petals to tips of wire.
steps.visual_description: A wire stem with a half-circle spray of wires, with the first 30 paper petals being glued to the tips.

steps.instruction: Glue another 30-60 petals between by attaching petal to petal.
steps.visual_description: A partially formed hydrangea bloom with more petals being glued in between the existing ones.

steps.instruction: Use green pencil to mark center and grain of leaves then fold down center.
steps.visual_description: Two green paper leaves are shown. A green pencil is used to draw lines on the center and grain of the leaves, and the center is folded down.

steps.instruction: Glue 3 leaves to underside of flower dome.
steps.visual_description: A completed hydrangea bloom with three green leaves being glued to the underside.

projects.finished_product_description: A realistic-looking paper hydrangea bloom with a stem and leaves.

diagram_descriptions: A collage of 10 step-by-step images showing how to create painted paper hydrangea blooms.
A large header image showing two finished paper hydrangeas with green leaves against a wooden background. The text 'PAINTED PAPER HYDRANGEA BLOOMS' and 'LIAGRIFFITH.COM' is overlaid on the image.

projects.name: DIY Paper Leaves
tips: Use a pattern trick to create folded paper leaves
projects.finished_product_description: A collection of colorful, folded paper leaves in various sizes and shapes, resembling autumn foliage.

diagram_descriptions: A top-down view of several folded paper leaves arranged on a white background. The leaves are in shades of green, yellow, and orange, and are folded in a fan-like pattern to create a textured, dimensional effect. Some leaves are larger and more elaborate, resembling maple or oak leaves, while others are smaller and more elongated, like willow or birch leaves. The arrangement is scattered and organic.

projects.name: Leaf Creation

steps.instruction: Fold a paper into half and draw a pattern and then complete the following steps to create the leaf!
steps.visual_description: The text describes a technique where a paper is folded in half and a pattern is drawn on it to create a leaf. This is followed by a mention of 'following steps' which are not detailed on this page.

tips: I came up with these 7 templates for now. I'm sure you can come up with more. But I'm pretty sure that you can come up with more awesome patterns with the help of this technique.

templates.name: Template 1
templates.shape_description: A right-angled triangle with the right angle at the bottom left.

templates.name: Template 2
templates.shape_description: A right-angled triangle with the right angle at the top left.

templates.name: Template 3
templates.shape_description: A quarter circle with a straight line forming the radius and another straight line forming the diameter.

templates.name: Template 4
templates.shape_description: A shape resembling a stepped leaf, with three steps on the left edge and a straight bottom and right edge.

templates.name: Template 5
templates.shape_description: A curved shape resembling the top half of a leaf, with a straight bottom edge and a curved top edge.

templates.name: Template 6
templates.shape_description: A shape with a straight bottom and right edge, and a left edge that is a series of curves forming a scalloped pattern.

templates.name: Template 7
templates.shape_description: A shape with a straight bottom and right edge, and a left edge that is a series of curves forming a scalloped pattern, similar to Template 6 but with fewer curves.

diagram_descriptions: A photograph showing scissors, a pencil, and a bottle of craft glue on a piece of orange paper, arranged on a white surface.
A sheet of paper with three triangular shapes and one quarter-circle shape drawn on it.
A sheet of paper with two leaf-like templates drawn on it. The top template has a stepped edge, and the bottom template has a smooth curved edge.
A sheet of paper with a template drawn on it that has a straight right edge and a scalloped left edge.
A sheet of paper with a template drawn on it that has a straight right edge and a scalloped left edge, similar to the previous template but with fewer scallops.

projects.name: Leaf Pattern - 1

steps.instruction: Take a square size paper and cut it diagonally to create 2 triangles.
steps.visual_description: Two images showing a square orange paper and then the same square paper cut diagonally into two triangles.

steps.instruction: Make small and even accordion folds on any one of the triangle papers.
steps.visual_description: Image showing a triangle paper folded into accordion pleats.

steps.instruction: Hold the center of the folded paper and squeeze it gently to bring the center folds together.
steps.visual_description: Image showing a hand holding the center of the accordion-folded triangle paper and squeezing it.

steps.instruction: Apply glue along any one side of the inner fold and join the inner sides to form the leaf.
steps.visual_description: Two images showing the folded paper being glued and joined to form a leaf shape.

steps.instruction: Allow the glue to dry.
steps.visual_description: Image showing a finished folded paper leaf.

projects.finished_product_description: A leaf shape made from folded and glued paper.

projects.name: Leaf Pattern - 2
projects.finished_product_description: This section shows the process of creating a different leaf pattern, but the instructions are missing.

diagram_descriptions: Step 3: A series of images demonstrating how to create a folded paper leaf. The first image shows a square orange paper. The second shows it cut diagonally. The third shows one triangle folded into accordion pleats. The fourth shows the center being squeezed. The fifth and sixth show the paper being glued and joined to form a leaf shape. The seventh image shows a finished leaf.

Step 4: A series of images showing the creation of a second leaf pattern. The first image shows a long strip of folded orange paper. The second shows a shorter section of the same folded paper. The third shows a folded paper with a diagonal crease. The fourth shows a long, thin triangle shape. The fifth image shows a folded paper in a triangular shape. The sixth image shows a long, thin, accordion-folded shape.
